scenes.location: COP CAR DRIVING BILLBOARD ROAD NIGHT 3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILDRED HAYES, a woman in her early 50's, driving along a country road, passes an old billboard, roadside. Whatever advert was on it is long since faded and torn. MILDRED dr on, to a second billboard a few hundred feet along the ro She notices this one a little more, though its old advert are equally ramshackle. She slows to a stop. After looking up at the billboard a while, she slowly reverses and stops at the first, then at all three, stretching away to the quiet horizon. Makes a mental note of “EBBING BILLBOARD ADVERTISING”, th drives on again, leaving the three old billboards alone l tombstones on the dusty road. INT. WELBY’S OFFICE - EBBING ADVERTISING - DAY 2 RED WELBY’s office, window looking onto MAIN STREET and t town's POLICE STATION. RED, a cool-looking young guy, pretends to read a Penguin Classic as he observes the off hottie, PAMELA, pass in a cute dress. MILDRED strides on

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: You Red Welby?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. How may I..

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: They said those three billboards out on Drinkwater Road, you're in charge of renting them out, that right?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: I didn’t know we had any billboards out on... Where is Drinkwater Road?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Road out past the Sizemore turn-off no- one uses since the highway got put in. RED checks a file. MILDRED observes a beetle on its back the windowsill, trying to right itself.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: You're right. Got three billboards out there. Nobody's put nothing up out there since... 1986. That was ‘Huggies’.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: How much to rent out all three of ‘em the year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The year? You wanna pay for three billboards on a road no-one goes down unless they got lost or they’re retards, for a year?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Quick, ain’t ya, Welby?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Well... since what I say goes these days down at the Ebbing Advertising Desk, I’m gonna strike you a real good deal’on those billboards, now, what was it you said your name was, Mrs...?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: What's the law on what ya can and can’t say on a billboard? I assume it’s ya can’t say nothing defamatory, and ya can’t say, ‘Fuck’ ‘Piss’ or ‘Cunt’. That right?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Or... Anus.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Well I think I'll be alright then. Here’s five thousand for the first month. I assume that'll cover it. She plonks down five thousand dollars cash.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And here’s what the billboards oughta say. She hands him three index cards, then moves to the window reads the first, the second, the third. Stunned.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don’t ya draw up a little contract betwixt us while you're at it, make sure no-one rents them billboards out. from under me? Welby looks up at her sadly.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: I guess you're Angela Hayes’ mother.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: That’s right, I’m Angela Hayes’ mother. MILDRED, at window, gently sets the beetle back upright. waddles off happily. Behind it, the U.S flag flutters abo the police station, as a couple of laughing COPS enter it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name's Mildred. How long before you've got ‘em put up?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: (checking calendar) Oh, shall we say by... Easter Sunday? MILDRED stares out at the police station.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: That'd be perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFFICER DIXON, 35, drives up the billboard road and approaches, FROM BEHIND, the THIRD billboard. Two LATINO WORKMEN work on it, buckets and squeegees. As he passes h looks up at the posters on it, double-takes, SCREECHES to halt. The billboard reads, in large, stark letters “HOW COME, C WILLOUGHBY?”.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Hey! What the Hell’s this?!

dialogues.speaker: LATINO
dialogues.text: Que?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: “How come Chief Willoughby?” what?

dialogues.speaker: LATINO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: LATINO
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: How come what?

dialogues.speaker: LATINO
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Listen, I better start getting some straight answers outta you Mexican sons of bitches... The 2ND LATINO has pointed to the distant SECOND billboar making an odd little gesture, and DIXON looks over...  DIXON’S POV: 4. The back of the second billboard, and the BLACK GUY finishing up with the posters there. END POV. DIXON sighs, drives off towards it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIXON swings his car around to the front of the billboard. It reads “AND STILL NO ARRESTS?” The black guy, JEROME, is emptying out JEROME turns JEROME reads JEROME spits stares back; his buckets.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: (to himself) What the Hell is this? (to JEROME) Hey you? What the fuck is this?

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: What the fuck is what?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: This! This! around and reads, as if for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: Advertising, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Advertising what? it again.

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: Something obscure?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: T/ll say!

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: Don’t I know your face from some place?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I dunno, do ya?

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, I do. on the ground, looks at him with disdain. DIXON a vicious edge between them.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I could arrest you right now, if I wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For... emptying out your bucket there. It’s against the... being bad against the environment laws.

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: Well, before you do that, Officer Dixon, why don’t you go have yourself a look at that first billboard over there, and then we can have ourself a talk about the motherfucking environment. How about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIXON looks at the distant FIRST BILLBOARD, standing all alone, back to us, the dark sky behind it. DIXON sighs, starts his car, pulls away. We go with him, staying on his face, as he comes to the F BILLBOARD and slowly stops in front of it. His face falls

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Fuck me. He takes out his cellphone, and presses “WILLOUGHBY (HOME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHIEF OF POLICE BILL WILLOUGHBY, 50, having dinner with h young wife, ANNE, mid-30’s, and his two daughters, POLLY, and JANE, 7. The telephone rings.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Don't... WILLOUGHBY, sheepish, answers it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Dixon, you goddam asshole, I’m in the middle of my goddam Easter dinner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIXON is out of the car now, pacing.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I know, Chief, and I’m sorry for calling ya at home and all, but uh, I think we've got kind of a problem... As DIXON passes out of frame, the FIRST BILLBOARD is revealed. It reads “RAPED WHILE DYING”. WIDE SHOT of the three billboards stretching away to the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILDRED drives ROBBIE, her 17-year-old son, past the billboards - checking his reaction. He sees them but give nothing away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drops him at school. He heads off without a goodbye. EXT. MAIN STREET - DAY 7c She drives up MAIN STREET. Sees activity outside the poli station; WILLOUGHY with his DESK SERGEANT, forcibly telli DIXON to stay behind, then crossing street to RED’s place

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues to the other end of town, a GIFT SHOP she w at. MILDRED’s co-worker, DENISE, black, 28, smokes outsid

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late, Denise.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Did you put up those billboards to fuck with the cops yet?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: They're up.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: You go, girl! You go fuck those cops up! She pats MILDRED on the back, tosses her cigarette away, they go inside. INT. WELBY’S OFFICE - DAY 8 Quick-fire dialogue, RED at desk, DESK SERGEANT and WILLOUGHBY standing.

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: What the fuck do you think you’re doing, Welby, buncha billboards like that, you didn’t think there’d be some kinda ramifications? Legally?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: What's the legal ramifications, Cedric?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to explain the legal ramifications, a little punk like you? And don’t call me Cedric.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Ain’t contravening no laws on wropriety, ain’t contravening no laws on any fucking thing. I checked all this up.

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, where’d you check all this up?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: In a... book.

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Which book, genius?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Book called ‘Suck my ass, it’s none o! your business’. WILLOUGHBY gives him a long cold stare.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: How long has this person, or persons, rented these billboards out for?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Oh, the year.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: And how long she actually paid for?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: The year.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: So it’s a she, huh?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: (pause) Ain’t at liberty to divulge that kinda information, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Mildred Hayes, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Ain't at liberty to divulge that kinda information, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Do you really wanna fuck with the Ebbing Police Department, Red? Do ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess. INT. POLICE STATION, WILLOUGHBY’S OFFICE - DAY WILLOUGHBY, DESK SERGEANT and DIXON.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: He said what?! To your face?!

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: No crime has been committed here.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Defamation of character ain’t a crime?

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: It isn’t defamation if she’s simply asking a question.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: What are you, an idiot?

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Don’t call me an idiot, Dixon.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I didn’t call you an idiot. I asked if you was an idiot. It was a question.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: (smiling) He got ya, Cedric!

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Well I’m gonna do something about it if yous two ain’t.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Where you going? Don’t fly off the handle! But Dixon has already stormed out.

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Why in hell you keep that man on, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: He's a good man. At heart.

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: He tortured a guy in custody, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: There was no... real evidence to support that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As WELBY is coming out of his building, DIXON crosses the road towards him.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Take ‘em down.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Hah?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Take ‘em down.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Take what down?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: You think I wouldn’t take you out, right here on Main Street, Red?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Thought you only take out black dudes, Dixon... DIXON goes to punch him, but WILLOUGHBY is suddenly there grabs his punching arm and shoves him towards the station People on the street are staring, especially the blacks.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: (to WELBY) Ain’t nobody never goes down that road, anyways. Unless they got lost, or they're retards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILDRED interviewed by GABRIELLA, CAMERAMAN filming, all three billboards in the background.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLA
dialogues.text: This your first time on tv?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLA
dialogues.text: Well, don’t be nervous, is the main thing, and it'll be fine. Just don’t look into the camera, obviously. MILDRED just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In three, two, one. So, Mildred Hayes, why did you put up these billboards?  14 15 10.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Well, my daughter, Angela, she got abducted, and she got raped and murdered seven months ago, on this self-same stretch o’ road here, unfortunately, and, to me... I mean, to me, it seems like the local police department is too busy goin’ round torturing black folks to be bothered doing anything about solving actual crime, so I kinda thought these here billboards might, y’know, concentrate their minds some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIXON sits beside his MOMMA on the couch and is just to b into a sandwich...

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Whatcha watching, Momma? The stupid news? ++.when he’s stopped by MILDRED’s appearance on TV...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (TV)
dialogues.text: Seems like the local police department is too busy goin’ round torturing black folks to be bothered doing anything about solving actual crime... DIXON’S MOMMA looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: (mouthing) Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLOUGHBY and ANNE watching the end of the interview.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (TV)
dialogues.text: I don’t know what these policemen are doing, to be honest with you. I just know my daughter’s burnt body’s lying six feet under the ground while they’re eating Krispy Kremes and busting eight year-olds for skateboarding in parking lots.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLA, (TV)
dialogues.text: And what has Chief Willoughby to do with all this, why single him out?  16 a7 18 ll.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (TV)
dialogues.text: Well, he’s the head of ‘em, ain’t he? The buck’s gotta stop at somebody, don’t it?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLA, (TV)
dialogues.text: And the buck stops at Willoughby?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (TV)
dialogues.text: Yeah, the buck stops at Willoughby. Dead right it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clicks it off, gets up, goes out of the house without word. EXT. WILLOUGHBY’S STABLE - NIGHT 16 WILLOUGHBY moodily tending the horses in the stable just outside the house. ANNE comes up.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You alright there, fella?

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Looks like we got a war on our hands. EXT. MILDRED’S HOUSE - DAWN ay WILLOUGHBY pulls up outside MILDRED’s poor, clapboard hou From here we can see that the BILLBOARDS puncturing the d horizon are only A MILE AWAY. MILDRED sees WILLOUGHBY fro the kitchen window, as he knocks. She opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Can we talk? EXT. MILDRED’S GARDEN - DAY 18 MILDRED sitting on a creaky swing-set, WILLOUGHBY with ha hand.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: I'd do anything to catch the guy who did it, Mrs Hayes. But when the DNA don’t match no-one who's ever been arrested, and when the DNA don’t match any other crime nationwide, and when there wasn’t a single eyewitness from the time she left your house to the time we found her, well, right now there ain’t too much more that we can do, except...  12.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Could pull blood from every man and boy in this town, over the age of eight.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: There's civil rights laws prevents that, Mrs Hayes, and what if he was just passing thru town...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Pull blood from ever’ man in the country, then.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: And what if he was just passing thru the country?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: If it was me, I'd start up a database, every male baby what’s born, stick ‘em on it, cross-reference it, and as soon as they done something wrong, make a hundred percent certain it was a correct match, then kill ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, there’s definitely civil rights laws prevents that. He sits on the swing beside her, the billboards stretchin out down the hill in front of them. WILLOUGHBY (CONT’D) I’m doing everything I can to track him down, Mrs Hayes. I don’t think those billboards is very fair.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: The time it’s took you to come out here whining like a bitch, Willoughby, some other poor girl's probably being butchered right now, but it’s good you've got your priorities straight, Ill say that for ya.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: There's something else, Mildred. (pause) I got cancer. I’m dying.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I know it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Huh?  22

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I know it. Most everbody in town knows it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: You know it, and you still put those billboards up?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Well, they wouldn't be as effective after you croak, right? WILLOUGHBY looks at her in disbelief, gets in his car, dr off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Town's main bar, WELBY shooting pool against JAMES, a loc dwarf, who uses a box to stand on. JAMES smacks a good on from a distance. DIXON comes up, drunk.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Well looky looky, if it ain’t the instigator of this whole goddam affair in the first place...

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: I didn’t instigate shit, Dixon...

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Playing pool against the town midget. JAMES pots another.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: He’s right, Red, you are playing pool against the town midget.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Well he’s a cop, y'know, he’s observant.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: You know, I always disliked you, Red, ever since you was a snotty little child, which you still look like. A snotty little child.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Well that’s unfortunate. I always thought you was great. JAMES plays a safety shot. WELBY takes over.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Even your name, ‘Red Welby’. Even your name I disliked.  14.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Well... okay.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Like you was some kind of a goddam Communist or something, and proud of it.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: No, it’s cos I got red hair. WELBY misses.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Do you know what they do to faggots down in Cuba, Welby?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Wow, that’s left-field... No, what do they do to faggots down in Cuba, Dixon?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: They kill ‘em! Which, it might surprise you to learn, T am against.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: I’m not sure if they do kill faggots down in Cuba, Dixon. I know Cuba’s human rights record is pretty deplorable when it comes to homosexuality, but killing ‘em? Are you sure you ain’t thinking of Wyoming?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Always with the smart-ass... JAMES smashes in another.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus! He’s quite good, isn’t he? (pause) Willoughby’s a good man, Red. He shouldn’t have this be the only thing he thinks about, the last months left to him.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: The last months what?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Oh. You didn’t know. Yeah. Pancreatic. RED is shaken. Out of nowhere, MILDRED idles over, puts a bunch of quarters on the pool table.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I’m up next if any of you ole ladies ever quit yakking.  24 15. She hangs there, staring them down.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Rude.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Saw you on TV the other day, Mildred.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yeah, you looked good. She stares at him. An embarrassed pause.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, y'know, you came across really good, in the things you were saying. Embarrassed, JAMES goes back to the pool.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I didn’t think you came across really good in the things you were saying. I thought you came across stupid-ass.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Ain’t it about time you got home to your momma, Dixon?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: No it ain’t time I got home to my momma. I tole her I was gonna be out til twelve. Actually. JAMES whacks in the black brilliantly from a distance... DIXON (CONT’D) Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Me v. you, Mildred! He smiles at her. INT. MILDRED’S HOUSE - NIGHT 24 MILDRED enters, a beer in hand, a bit drunk...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Hey Robbie? I think that midget wants to get in my pants... ...to find FATHER MONTGOMERY, an old priest she knows, at kitchen table beside ROBBIE, best teacups in front of the  16.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Father Montgomery.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Mildred. I'm sorry for calling on you so late, although I must say Robbie's been the consummate host. Despite his having, he was just telling me, something of a tricky day at school.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh, no, just some of the guys on the team was giving me crap.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Crap about what?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: About the billboards. Which is, uh, kind of what I’ve come to have a word with you about, Mildred.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Oh. Proceed.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I know it’s been hard for you, Mildred, this past year. We all do. The whole town does. And whatever it is you need, we'll be there for you. Always. But the town also knows what kind of a man William Willoughby is. And the town is dead set against these billboards of yours.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Took a poll, did ya, Father?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: If you hadn't stopped coming to church, Mildred, you’d be aware of the depth of people’s feelings. I had a dozen people come up to me on Sunday. So, yes, I took a poll. Everybody is on your side about Angela. No-one’s on your side about this.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: ¥/know what I was thinking about, earlier today? I was thinking ‘bout those streetgangs they got in Los Angeles, the Crips and the Bloods? I was thinking about that buncha new laws they came up with, in the 80’s I think it was, to combat those street-gangs, those Crips and those Bloods. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 She goes off teacup.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And, if I remember rightly, the gist of what those new laws said was, if you join one of these gangs, and you're running with ‘em, and down the block from you one night, unbeknownst to you, your fellow Crips, or your fellow Bloods, shoot up a place, or stab a guy, well, even though you didn’t know nothing about it, even though you may’ve just been standing on a streetcorner minding your own business, those new laws said you are still culpable. You are still culpable, by the very act of joining those Crips, or those Bloods, in the first place. Which got me thinking, Father, that whole type of situation is kinda similar to you Church boys, ain’t it? You've got your colors, you've got your clubhouse, you're, for want of a better word, a gang. And if you're upstairs smoking a pipe and reading a bible while one of your fellow gang members is downstairs fucking an altar boy then, Father, just like the Crips, and just like the Bloods, you're culpable. Cos you joined the gang, man. And I don’t care if you never did shit or never saw shit or never heard shit. You joined the gang. You’re culpable. And when a person is culpable to altar-boy-fucking, or any- kinda-boy-fucking, I know you guys didn’t really narrow it down, then they kinda forfeit the right to come into my house and say a word about me, or my life, or my daughter, or my billboards. So, why don’t you just finish your tea there, Father, and get the fuck outta my kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to another room. MONTGOMERY puts down his

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: But thanks for coming up anyway, Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i. 25 DOCTOR drawing WILLOUGHBY’s blood as he looks away from i squeamish, out the window at the pretty landscape.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: How you been feeling, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Oh, like I got cancer in a major organ.  26 27 18.

dialogues.text: Well I just want you to know, we're all on your side about this Mildred Hayes thing...

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: If I have to hear that one more fucking time...! WILLOUGHBY wrenches the needle from his arm, and tosses t vial at a wall, where it smashes and splatters.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m done with this shit. I can’t waste my life waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: DIXON

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Late night?  30 19.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Or you'll do what?

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Or I’ll kick your Momma’s teeth in.

dialogues.text: No you won't. (pause) Who told ya I was laying on him anyway? The midget?

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you talking about?! Fucking midgets! I’m trying to fucking concentrate! DIXON shrugs. WILLOUGHBY, goes back to the file. DIXON ambles, bored. WILLOUGHBY crouches, runs his fingers thru burnt soil there, looking like he might cry.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: What are you looking for, anyway? There’s nothing to look for. INT. DENTIST’S SURGERY - DAY 30 MILDRED in a dentist’s chair.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I don’t know what it is. The filling feels like it’s kinda waggling. GEOFFREY, a fat dentist, appears, with his instruments.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Well if it’s waggling it’s gonna haveta come out.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (bemused) Ain’t you gonna have a look at it first? GEOFFREY does so, perfunctorily.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: It’s gonna haveta come out. Bemused, she guesses he knows what he’s doing. He fiddles among his drills, comes up with a high pitched one.  31 20.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Uh, can I get a little Novocaine, there, Doc? He puts the drill down, gets a syringe, injects in under gum at painful angles and length, takes it out and looks his watch, just sitting there.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Give it a couple minutes.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (pause) Maybe it wasn’t waggling. Maybe it was just my fingers going in and out. Silence. He picks up the drill again, gets it going.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: I just wanted to say... There’s a lotta good friends of Bill Willoughby in this town, Mrs Hayes, who don’t take kindly to... But MILDRED has already grabbed the drill hand, then grab the hand that was holding her mouth open. She slowly star bringing one hand towards the other, the whirring drill aiming towards his big fat thumbnail. GEOFFREY is too flabby, and MILDRED too forceful, for him do anything about it but whimper, as... CLOSE UP: The drill gets closer and closer to his thumbna GEOFFREY sweating... MILDRED determined... +.,until finally the drill WHIRS INTO THE NAIL, splitting right down the center, then continuing DEEPER, whirring i the bloody flesh under the nail until the nail spins off altogether.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Then why don’t you tell those good friends of Bill Willoughby to tell Bill Willoughby to go do his fucking job, fat boy. She pushes the screaming bloody dentist out of the way, rinses her mouth out with the pink stuff, spits it at his head, and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENISE behind counter, MILDRED arranging knickknacks. Cop pulls up, lights flashing. WILLOUGHBY and DIXON enter.  21.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Hey there, Mildred! You didn’t happen to pay a Visit to the dentist today, did ya? MILDRED's dialogue hereon is thru a totally unintelligibl Novocained mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (unintelligibly) No.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (unintelligibly) Said ‘No’.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Oh. So it wasn’t you who drilled a little hole in one of big fat Geoffrey’s big fat thumbnails, no?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (unintelligibly) Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (unintelligibly) I said “Of course not.”

dialogues.speaker: DENISE

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (unintelligibly) No, Denise, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Well, I thought it was kinda funny myself, but he wants to press charges, so we're gonna have to bring you in, I’m afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIXON guarding door. MILDRED looking out window.  22. MILDRED'S POV: Across the road, WELBY and PAMELA are look out at the pedestrians in the sunshine. WELBY’s obviously into her, but shy about it. END POV. MILDRED smiles. The novocaine’s worn off.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: So how's it all going in the nigger- torturing business, Dixon?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: It’s ‘Persons of color’-torturing business, these days, if you want to know. And I didn’t torture nobody. She idles back to the table and sits. DIXON (CONT’D) Goddam saying that goddam stuff on TV. My momma watches that station!

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: And she didn’t know nothing about the torturing?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: No she didn’t know anything about it. She’s against that kinda thing. WILLOUGHBY breezes in.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Who's against what kinda thing?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: My momma. Is against ‘Persons-of-color torturing’. She said ‘nigger-torturing’. I said you can’t say ‘nigger-torturing’ no more. You gotta say ‘Persons-of-color’ torturing. Right?

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: I think I’11 be able to take care of Mrs Hayes on my own from hereon, Jason.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Sure, Chief, I’1l be right outside if you need me. DIXON gives WILLOUGHBY a pat on the back as he leaves. WILLOUGHBY sits with some papers.  He smiles at of the desk, 23.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Don’t gimme that look. If you got rid of every cop with vaguely racist leanings then you'd have three cops left and all o’ them are gonna hate the fags so what are ya gonna do, y'know? MILDRED, then comes round and sits on her side looking down on her. WILLOUGHBY (CONT’D) I wanna know something, Mildred...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Does sitting up high like that make you feel more powerful, Chief?

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Mildred, I’1l go sit where I was if it makes you feel more comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I didn’t say I was uncomfortable. I don’t get uncomfortable around cops. Sit wherever you want. It’s your police station.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Why'd ya drill a hole thru poor fat Geoffrey's thumbnail?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Oh, that didn’t happen. His hand slipped and he drilled a hole thru his self. Is he saying I done it? Jeez, then I guess it’s just his word against mine, huh? Kinda like in all those rape cases you hear about. Except, in this instance, the chick ain’t losing.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: It ain’t really about winning or losing, though, is it, Mildred? I mean, do you think I care about who wins or loses between the two of yous? Do you think I care about dentists? I don’t care about dentists. Nobody cares about dentists! I do care about, or I’m interested in, tying you up in court so long that your hours at the gift shop are so shot to shit that you ain’t got a penny to pay for another months billboards. I’m interested in that.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I got some dough put away...  24.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: What I heard was you had to sell off your ex-husband’s tractor-trailer to even pay for this month’s billboards, that right? (pause) How is ole Charlie, by the way? He still shacked up with that pretty little intern works down at the zoo?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: He’s still shacked up with some chick who smells of shit. I don’t know if the z0o’s got anything to do with it. Although I'd hope so.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: How old is she? Nineteen? That must smart.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Keep trying, Officer. Keep trying.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: What’s Charlie think about these here billboards of yours, an ex-cop like Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Ex-cop, ex-wife-beater. Same difference, I guess, right?

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: His word against yours, though, right? (pause) Charlie don’t know about them, does he?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: It’s none of his business.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: He's kinda paying for ‘em though, ain't he?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I’m paying for ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: This month you are. How about when... WILLOUGHBY suddenly let’s out a short sharp cough which spurts a spray of blood that hits MILDRED in the face, wh by accident. Horrified, shaking, WILLOUGHBY tries to wipe face with a handkerchief, MILDRED almost in tears at his embarrassment. WILLOUGHBY (CONT’D) I didn’t mean to...  33 34 35 25.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I know...

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: It was an accident...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I know, baby.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: It's blood.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I know. They're both in tears, and there’s a desperation in his e as he sits there shaking.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I/1l go get somebody... She rushes out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLOUGHBY is gurneyed into an ambulance past TOWNS-PEOPL DIXON beside him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY

dialogues.text: MILDRED, still stunned, wipes the remaining spots of bloo from her face, as TOWNS-PEOPLE (including the bandaged GEOFFREY and a LADY WITH A FUNNY EYE) come up to her angr and, oddly, JEROME drives a remote-controlled jeep along sidewalk towards them.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Any of you funny-eyed fuckers even think about touching those billboards, you will fucking die. You got that? You will fucking die. JEROME drives his toy car into GEOFFREY’s ankle.

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: Yeah, leave her alone. Those billboards are cool! JEROME picks up his jeep and heads off, and MILDRED is le to walk away alone, the TOWNSPEOPLE watching, GEOFFREY rubbing his ankle. From his second storey window, RED WELBY has been watchin the distant scene. He looks across at the police station, sees that DIXON has been watching HIM from his ground flo window. DIXON slowly closes his blinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILDRED driving ROBBIE home from school.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Do birds get cancer?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 27. ROBBIE (CONT’D) Cos if there was two seconds in a day when I didn’t think about her, and wasn't thinking about how she died, "There ya go, Robbie, think about it some more, why don’t ya?” It’s good, too, that as much as a person might’ve tried to avoid the details of what happened, cos he didn’t think it’d do any good, and he didn’t think he could bear it, it’s also good to be informed in twenty foot high lettering, and a real nice font, the precise details of her last moments, y'know? That it wasn’t enough that she was raped, and it wasn’t enough that she died, no. “Raped While Dying”. Thank you, mom.

dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah? INT. MILDRED’S HOUSE, KITCHEN - DAY FLASHBACK. It’s ten months ago. MILDRED washing dishes. ROBBIE drawing, ANGELA dressed to go out.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA

dialogues.text: Bitch!

dialogues.text: You are such a hypocrite!

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You drove drunk with us in the car when we was kids.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Daddy told me.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (pause) When did you see him?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I see him all the time, don’t change the subject. Did you or did you not drive drunk with us in the car when we was kids?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Once, maybe...

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Oh, ‘once,’ okay...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: .+.when he was in the middle of beating the shit out of me.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Which we've only got your word about, right?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA

dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (same time) Hey..! There’1ll be no more ‘Cunts’ in this house, you got that, Mister?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just walk, Angela? Why don’t you just walk?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You know what, I will walk, I will walk. And y'know what? I hope I get raped on the way.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well I hope you get raped on the way too! Door slams. FLASHBACK over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLOUGHBY in a bed, ANNE nearby, DOCTOR checking him.  30.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: We're gonna need to keep you in a few days, Bill. You shouldn't be coughing up blood.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I kinda guessed that, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I’ll swing by in the morning. Anne. DOCTOR departs, and we listen to his echoing footsteps as they look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Guess I’1l go get your coat, huh?

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Well you know I ain’t staying...

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: And you know I ain’t arguing. She smiles and goes out, footsteps echo away, leaving him alone there, in the sterile quiet. Scared. 40 EXT. MILDRED’S HOUSE - DAWN 40 A pretty pink sunrise over the hills behind the house. 408 INT. MILDRED’S HOUSE, KITCHEN - DAY 40B MILDRED and ROBBIE getting their breakfasts in silence, ROBBIE more moody than she is. She tries to make him laug he ignores her. Finally, she takes a big spoonful of milk cereal, and she slings it straight in his face and hair.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Slipped. Oops. She stares at him, deadpan, as milk and cereal drip down face and hair.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (suppressing laughter) I ain't old, Robbie

dialogues.text: That's dad.  41 42 31. He wipes his face, rushes to the door, MILDRED apprehensi EXT. MILDRED’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS 41 Her ex, CHARLIE, slams his car door shut and approaches t front door as ROBBIE opens it. CHARLIE’s nineteen year ol girlfriend, PENELOPE, remains in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Hey dad! How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where’s the crazy lady...? ROBBIE gestures inside and CHARLIE breezes in. ROBBIE wav to PENELOPE, who smiles and gives an embarrassed wave bac INT. MILDRED’S HOUSE, KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS 42 ROBBIE, CHARLIE and MILDRED, who's still finishing breakf

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The kid’s got Rice fucking Krispies in his fucking hair! What's going on around here? And what the fuck’s going on with these fucking billboards, Mildred?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Kinda self-explanatory, ain’t it?

dialogues.text: Well why don’t you just explain it to me?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Guess it ain't self-explanatory then. Well, y'know, I guess I wanted certain people's minds kept on certain people’s jobs, is all. I hadn’t heard a word from ‘em in seven goddam months, but I tell ya this, I heard an awful lot from ‘em since I put those billboards up...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You think this has focussed their minds? I'll tell you what it’s focussed their minds on. It’s focussed their minds on how exactly are they gonna fuck you up.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: The more you keep a case in the public eye, the better your chances of getting it solved, it’s in all the guidebooks, Charlie.  32.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How much those billboards cost?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: ‘Bout the same as a tractor-trailer. ROBBIE sniggers.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you laughing at?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Laughed at by a guy with fucking cereal in his hair!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: How’s Penelope?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Huh? She’s alright.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you invite her in, save leaving her sitting there?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: She's here?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She’s out in the car.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Oh. That explains it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That explains what?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I knew I could smell something. CHARLIE overturns the table violently and, as MILDRED bac away, grabs her by the neck and pins her against the wall Just as suddenly, a knife is placed against CHARLIE’s thr by ROBBIE, deadly serious.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Let her go. Just then, the sound of a screen door creaking is heard, PENELOPE is standing there, startled by the scene.  33.

dialogues.speaker: PENELOPE
dialogues.text: Oh, um, I kinda needed to use the bathroom, but if it’s inconvenient, actually it is inconvenient, isn’t it, I can see it’s inconvenient, I can hold it, it’s alright... CHARLIE lets go of MILDRED and ROBBIE lowers the knife.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE

dialogues.speaker: PENELOPE
dialogues.text: Are you sure? I feel like I’m intruding...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Just go pee! PENELOPE quickly heads down the hall to the toilet, leavi the three of them staring at each other. ROBBIE sets righ the upturned table.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: *Bout seven months ago.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Look, you’ve said what you came to say. Okay? Why don’t ya just go get zoo girl and get the hell out of my house? Alright? PENELOPE comes out of toilet, goes to the screen door, tu

dialogues.speaker: PENELOPE
dialogues.text: Um, actually, zoo-wise, they were letting people go at the zoo, unfortunately, and it was a case of “Last in, first out”, so, yeah, unfortunately the zoo had to let me go. But they were looking for people down at the horse-rides for the disableds, to look after the horses down there, so I’m working down there now, looking after the disableds horses, so... (pause) The horses aren’t disableds. The disableds are. (pause) I like all animals. She pauses again, then exits.  34.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Don’t say a word.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I wasn’t gonna say a word.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Don’t you think I don’t wish it had never happened?! Don’t you think I don’t wish she was here still?!

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I know you do. I know you do.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Billboards ain’t gonna bring her back, Mildred.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Neither is fucking nineteen year olds, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. But I know that.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (pause) Just go.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, alright, I’m such a shitty dad and you’re such a great mom. Alright. So how come a week before she died she comes around asking if she can move in with me at my place, cos she couldn't stand the two of yous bitching at each other no more, and fighting with each other no more...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And I said “No, stay at home, your mom loves you.” And now I wish I hadn't, cos if I hadn’t she’d still fucking be here!

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Don’t believe me. Ask Fruit Loop boy. CHARLIE leaves. Sound of his car pulling away.

She got killed, and now she'll be dead forever. I do thank you for coming up, though. If I had some food I'd give it ya, but I’ve only got some Doritos and I'd be scared they’d kill ya, they’re kinda pointy. Then where would we be? Blood seeping along the “Just telephone the boys” part of note (so only the words ‘The Just’ aren’t blood-covered). DESK SERGEANT winces as he opens the hood. INT. WILLOUGHBY HOUSE - NIGHT 56a WILLOUGHBY quietly finishing the note at the kitchen tabl ANNE’s drunken feet, in fun socks, visible on the distant couch. He puts it in an envelope marked ‘ANNE’, gets up, quietly leaves the house;

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: My darling Anne. There’s a longer letter in the dresser drawer I’ve been writing for the last week or so. That one covers us, and my memories of us, and how much I’ve always loved you. This one just covers tonight, and, more importantly, today. Tonight I have gone out to the horses to end it. I cannot say sorry for the act itself, although I know that for a short time you will be angry at me or even hate me for it. Please don’t. This is not a case of “I came in this world alone, and I’m going out of it alone” or anything dumb like that. I did not come in this world alone, my mom was there, and I am not. going out of it alone, cos you are there, drunk on the couch, making Oscar Wilde’ cock jokes. No. This is a case, in some senses, of bravery. Not the bravery of facing a bullet down; the next few months of pain would be far harder than that small flash. No, it’s the bravery of weighing up the next few months of still being with you, still waking up with you, of playing with the kids, against the next few months of seeing in your eyes how much my pain is killing you; how my weakened body as it ebbs away and you tend to it are your final and lasting memories of me. I won't have that. Your final memories of me will be us at the riverside, and that dumb fishing game (which I think they cheated at), and me inside of you, and you on top of me, and barely a fleeting thought of the darkness yet to come. That was the best, Anne. A whole day of not thinking about it. Dwell on this day, baby, cos it was the best day of my life. Kiss the girls for me, and know that I’ve always loved you, and maybe I'll see you again if there's another place. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And if there ain’t, well, it’s been Heaven knowing you. Your boy, Bill.

What appears to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound brought life to an end for Chief Willoughby, a man highly- respected in Ebbing for his diligence and his service to the community, a service that lasted more than 25 years. What led him to take his life in the early hours of this morning it is too early to speculate; (MORE)
