dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I can’t find my badge. No, seriously. Maybe I dropped it when Iwas doing the window guy?

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: Just get out of my station house, man. DIXON rises, sadly. Looks to his FELLOW COPS. Who look aw ABERCROMBIE enters WILLOUGHBY’s office, slams the door be him. DIXON shuffles up to the DESK SERGEANT.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I think I just got fired. Fired or suspended, I’m not sure which...

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Fired.  68 52. DIXON looks at him, eyes welling up. He nods, and leaves before he starts crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pick-up truck pulls up outside. MILDRED, reading a magazine, watches as a well-built, CROP-HAIRED GUY, late 20's, enters, kinda stares straight at her a moment, then ambles around the shop, looking at knickknacks he obvious has no use for. He stares at GUY tosses a

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Anything I can help you with, just gimme a holler.

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: (pause) Give you a what?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: A holler? her again, then continues with the knickknacks.

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: A holler, huh? (pause) Give Mildred Hayes a holler. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: You know me?

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: Only from the TV, and the radio. How much these here ‘Welcome to Missouri’ rabbits go for?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Seven bucks. It’s writ right on ‘em. glass rabbit against a distant shelf, where it, and the things on the shelf, shatter, startling MILDRED.

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: Guess he ain’t seven bucks now.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: What the Hell was it you come in here for?

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: What did I come in here for? Well, maybe I’m a good friend of Willoughby’s, how about that?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Are you?  53.

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: Or, y'know... maybe I was a friend of your daughter’s or something. How about that?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (pause) Were you?

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED MAN
dialogues.text: or, uh, y'know, maybe I was the guy who fucked her while she was dying? How about that? They stare at each other a while.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Were you?

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: Oh... Naw. I would've liked to. I saw her picture in the paper there. Door bell tinkles, as ANNE enters, dressed in black. CROP-HAIRED GUY (CONT’D) Saved by the bell, huh? GUY turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: You owe me seven fucking dollars for the rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: Guess you’ll have to get it off me next time I’m passing through, huh Mildred?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I guess I will. GUY exits. ANNE, who she’s never seen before, comes up.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t know how glad I am to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: That guy was scaring me.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have said you scare easy.  54.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I ain’t the worst. What can I do for you, ma’am?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: My husband left this for you before he shot himself in the head last night. ANNE hands her the letter, as MILDRED just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Mrs Willoughby...

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Are you? Are you really?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Of course...

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Surely it’s the perfect ending for you, isn’t it? It’s proof that they've been successful, these billboards of yours, isn’t it, a dead policeman? It’s quantifiable now.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Are you blaming this on me?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: No, I’m not blaming this on you. I just came to give you the letter. Now, my two little girls are out in the car, so I'd better not stay and chat. I’m not sure what we’re going to do for the rest of the day. It’s hard to know what to do the day your husband kills himself. It’s hard to know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNE leaves. MILDRED looks out as she drives away - and s POLLY and JANE looking back at her thru the rear window. MILDRED rests her head on the glass door a second, the br ‘WELCOME TO MISSOURI’ rabbit on the shelf beside her, its head split in two. She opens the letter in her hand and starts reading, as dusk falls on the street outside.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY
dialogues.text: Dear Mildred, Dead Man Willoughby here. Firstly I wanted to apologise for dying without catching your daughter's killer. It’s a source of great pain to me, and it would break my heart to think you thought I didn’t care, cos I did care. There are just some cases...  69 70 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The billboards and surrounding landscape from various ang at sunset; including details like the half-eaten flowers the insects thereon; the burnt patch of dirt; and the billboards themselves.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ..-where you never catch a break, then five years down the line some guy hears some other guy bragging about it in a bar-room or a jail-cell and the whole thing is wrapped up thru sheer stupidity. I hope that might be true for Angela, I really do. Second, I gotta admit, Mildred, the billboards were a great fucking idea. They were like a chess move. And although they had absolutely nothing to do with my dying, I’m sure that everyone in town will assume that they did, which is why, for Willoughby’s counter-move, I decided to pay the next month’s rent on ‘em. I thought it’d be funny, you having to defend ‘em a whole nuther month after they’ve stuck me in the ground. The joke is on you, Mildred, ha ha, and I hope they do not kill you. So good luck with all that, and good luck with everything else too. I hope and I pray that you get him. EXT. DIXON’S HOUSE - DUSK 70 DIXON and MOMMA sitting on their porch at sunset, with be

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA
dialogues.text: Well, do you want me to go down and talk to them?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: No I don’t want you to go down and talk to them. Jesus! Somebody sending their goddam mother down to talk to the goddam police, for Christ’s sakes. (pause) And say what?

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA
dialogues.text: And say to give you your job back. And to get rid of the black guy.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: They ain’t gonna listen to some guy’s mother, asking them to get rid of some black guy. Things have moved on in The South!  56.

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA
dialogues.text: Well it shouldn’t've! (pause) Will they give you any money for being laid off an’ all?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I don’t know what the compensation scheme is for when you throw a guy out of a window, Mom. I guess I shoulda looked into that beforehand. Let me Google that!

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA
dialogues.text: A couple grand, maybe? You've been there three years. Not counting the five years at the Academy. Six if you count the year you were held back. DIXON pulls on his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where ya going?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: None of your business.

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA
dialogues.text: Off to see your fancy woman?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I don’t got a fancy woman.

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA,
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know! He gives her a dirty look.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: You wanna watch yourself.

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA
dialogues.text: Or you'll do what?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Blow your goddam head off. MOMMA laughs loudly. Dixon gets in his car and drives off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILDRED and ROBBIE, driving a road adjacent to the billbo road, the billboards not yet in sight.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh, did you hear the news?  72 57.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: What news?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: That Dixon guy threw that Welby guy out his window this morning.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: You're shitting me. Is Welby okay? ROBBIE shrugs. MILDRED is sick to her stomach, and just w it seems like things can’t get any worse, she turns onto Billboard Road and suddenly sees...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're shitting me! ...ALL THREE OF THE BILLBOARDS ARE ON FIRE. MILDRED speed towards them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We speed towards the fiery billboards; the third totally ablaze, the second half-ablaze, words still legible, the first just getting going. MILDRED grabs the car’s extinguisher...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Go get the one from the house!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t I call the fire department?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Fuck the fire department! They probably started it!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Well don’t do anything stupid! But MILDRED’s already racing towards the first billboard, spraying it all over from close up. ROBBIE speeds off. MILDRED keeps spraying like a madwoman...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (quietly) Scumbags, scumbags, scumbags. Fucking scumbags. ...and finally gets the first billboard out, then sprints the way to the second, starts in on that. It’s harder thi time - the flames already halfway up. She gets an idea, concentrates all her efforts on the lef side post alone and, as it starts going out, she starts climbing up it, putting out the fire bit by bit as she go  73 58. Finally, all the left hand post is out and, though her ha are burnt, she gets to the top of the billboard and start walking along it, spraying down along its length. This starts to work, flames edging back, until tsss tsss, extinguisher runs out of stuff. She tosses it violently a the flames and stays standing there, staring at them, as flames slowly start to rise towards her again. Suddenly, ROBBIE pulls up, jumps out of the car and start on the flames below her.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing, Mom?! The flames start to come under control as MILDRED climbs back down. ROBBIE has the second billboard out by the tim she’s down, but the distant third is still raging. MILDRE starts marching off towards it...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Come on...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Leave it, Ma. It’s too late. MILDRED storms back and tries to grab the extinguisher of him, but he won't let it go. It’s paining her burnt hands terribly, but she keeps trying. ROBBIE (CONT’D) Mom, leave it, please! PAUSE. MILDRED makes one final effort. This time ROBBIE l it be taken. She strides off to the third billboard, tota engulfed in massive flame. He watches her start in on it, sighs, then heads off towards her, to try and help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. The fires out, the billboards smouldering. FIREMEN COPS idling. MILDRED’s hands are being treated by a MEDIC ROBBIE looks on. ABERCROMBIE comes over.

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: How are those hands? She ignores him. The MEDIC moves off. ABERCROMBIE (CONT’D) can I ask you a coupla questions?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: You can ask me all the questions you want if you take me down and arrest me.  16 7 59.

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna arrest you, Mrs Hayes. I got nothing to arrest you for.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Not yet you ain't. She walks off towards the second billboard and the car.

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: (to ROBBIE) We ain’t all the enemy, y'know? INT. MILDRED’S HOUSE, HER BEDROOM - MORNING 76 MILDRED lying awake, thinking. She slowly sits up, slips feet into her fluffy BUNNY RABBIT SLIPPERS at bedside, an sits there a while; worn out, angry, depressed.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (quietly) I‘ll crucify the motherfuckers. (crying) I'll crucify the motherfuckers. She flexes her toes in her bunny slippers, and the bunny noses look like they’re sniffing. It hits her how incongr the image is in regard to what she’s saying. She smiles. MILDRED's POV: of rabbit slippers, noses sniffing again.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (rabbit voice) What are you gonna do to ‘em, Mildred? You're gonna crucify ‘em, you say? (normal voice) That's right, I’m gonna crucify ‘em. (rabbit voice) Who you gonna crucify? The motherfuckers? (normal voice) That's right, the motherfuckers. (rabbit voice) Jeez! Well, I guess those motherfuckers better watch out then, huh? (normal voice) Fucking A!

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CAR DRIVING BILLBOARD ROAD
dialogues.text: MILDRED and ROBBIE approaching the burned out, blackened billboards, and see GABRIELLA and her NEWS CREW at the se of them. They slow down to a crawl, to listen...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: What’s this shit...?  78 79 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIELLA continuing, doing a little walk past the billbo for the camera, which pans with her...

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLA
dialogues.text: .+.and as sad as the spectacle of these burned out billboards might be, in light of the death of Chief Willoughby, this reporter for one can’t help but wonder whether this finally puts an end to the strange saga of the three billboards outside of Eb... MILDRED calling from the car...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: This don’t put an end to shit, you fucking retard, this is just the fucking start, so why don’t you put that on your "Good Morning Missouri fucking Wake-Up Broadcast”, bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILDRED drives off at speed from the open-mouthed GABRIEL who finally gives the CAMERAMAN the sign to cut. EXT. DIXON’S HOUSE - DAY 79 DIXON reading a comic book on the porch, beer in hand. MO comes out, worried.

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA
dialogues.text: I see on the TV there was a buncha fires lit outside o’ town last night.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Buncha fires, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA,
dialogues.text: Out at those billboards.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, back when I was a cop I woulda been interested in who set those fires cos, technically, that’s arson, but as I am no longer employed by those people I don’t really give a good god damn, now do I? Telephone rings, they look at each other. DIXON goes into house and gets it. DIXON (CONT’D) The Dixon residence. Oh, hey Sarge! How you doing? You got any news?  80 81 82 83 61.

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: News about what?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I dunno, about my job and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DESK SERGEANT at desk, squad room busy, ABERCROMBIE talki to other COPS in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: No, no. What? No. Anne Willoughby just dropped in a letter that Bill wrote you before he died.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Oh my God! What's it say?

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I haven't read it, Dixon, it’s not my letter.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, I’11 come right down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DESK SERGEANT looks at the distant ABERCROMBIE and the CO listening to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: him...

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Well, wh... I don’t think that’d be such a great idea, as things stand, Jason. Uh, you’ve still got your keys to the station-house though, right?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Well, why don’t you just come pick it up when everyone’s gone home. I can leave it on your desk for ya.

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Actually, yeah, then when you're done you can just leave your keys, save us picking ‘em up later. DIXON nods, so he won't have to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dark street at night. Inside the lowered blinds of th police station there’s the faint glow of a flashlight. INT. POLICE STATION - NIGHT 85a DIXON in the dark, empty station with a flashlight, eatin Doritos, headphones on, looks at the “OFFICER JASON DIXON envelope on his desk, beside Angela’s file. He opens it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Jason, Willoughby here. I’m dead now, sorry about that, but there’s something I wanted to say to you that I never really said when I was alive. I think you've got the makings of being a really good cop, Jason, and you know why? Because, deep down, you're a decent man. I know you don’t think I think that, but I do, Dipshit. You play hopscotch when you think no-one’s looking, for Christ's sakes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Street deserted as MILDRED, with backpack, checks to see one’s watching then slips inside thru the taped up door o WELBY’s offices.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I do think you're too angry, though, .. INT. WELBY’S OFFICE - NIGHT 87 MILDRED at WELBY’s desk in his swivel chair, phone-book o to ‘Ebbing Police Precinct House’, telephone to her ear, backpack on table, broken window looking out on the dark police station across the street.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ++.And I know it’s all since your dad died and you had to go look after your Mom and all...  88 89 90 91 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telephone on DESK SERGEANT’s desk starts ringing, red lig flashing, but as DIXON still has his headphones on he can hear it. Phone stops ringing after a while.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: ++sBut as long as you hold onto so much hate then I don’t think you're ever going to become... INT. WELBY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS 89 MILDRED gets up and exits frame with her backpack, leavin just the table, window and the police station in shot. SO ONLY of four clinking bottles taken out of backpack. MILD moves back into shot, looks at the phone again.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ++.What I know you wanna become...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIXON walking around the station, reading tearfully. Pass DESK SERGEANT’s desk, as phone starts ringing again. He s can’t hear it. After five or six rings it stops.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ++.A Detective. INT. WELBY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS 91 MILDRED looks at the phone she’s just put down, thinking, rolling a cigarette lighter around in her hand, thumbing flint but not lighting it, until...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Fuck ‘em! She lights the lighter, and we pan with her and finally s the FOUR MOLOTOV COCKTAILS she’s placed on the table. She quickly picks up and lights the first, moves to the window and launches it high out across the street. It explodes BELOW DIXON’S WINDOW, setting it and the whole w alight.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Cos you know what you need to become a detective? And I know you’re gonna wince when I say this...  92 93 94 95 96 97 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIXON hasn’t noticed the sound or the flames. He turns th letter to the 2nd page.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...But what you need to become a detective... is Love. DIXON winces.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Because thru Love comes Calm, and thru Calm comes Thought. And you need Thought to detect stuff sometimes, Jason. It’s kinda all you need. INT. WELBY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS 93 MILDRED tosses the second Molotov out...

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You don’t even need a gun. And you definitely don’t need Hate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hits the SECOND STOREY WINDOWS, setting them alight.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hate never solved nothing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIXON is wrapped up in the letter, chewing his fingernail flames leaping behind him

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: But Calm did. And Thought did. Try it. Try it just for a change. No-one’ll think you're gay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. WELBY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS 96 MILDRED tosses the third Molotov out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third Molotov hits THE POLICE STATION DOOR, setting it alight.  98 99 100 101 65.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And if they do, arrest ‘em for homophobia! Won't they be surprised!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flames still leap outside DIXON’s window as DIXON, his ba to it, keeps reading.

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Good luck to you, Jason. You're a decent man, and yeah you've had a run of bad luck... INT. WELBY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS 99 IN SLOWMO, MILDRED tosses out the final Molotov...

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: +..But things are gonna change for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN SLOWMO, the Molotov arcs up across the street...

dialogues.speaker: WILLOUGHBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I can feel it. +++and IN NORMAL SPEED, SMASHES IN THRU DIXON'S WINDOW...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIXON finally notices this one, as it explodes behind him knocks him off his feet, his desk and that whole side of room set ablaze. He sees that the station door is on fire also, blocking his exit, and the ANGELA HAYES file on his desk’ on fire too. He grabs and pats it against himself, getting the flames but getting petrol all over himself in the process. DIXON looks around, checks a locked back door, and realis there is no way out of the building other than thru his o the fiery broken window.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Calm. Calm. Standing in front of the window, he looks down at the fil places it safely up inside his shirt, hugs it tightly to chest, takes a few steps back, then makes a running leap, headfirst thru the flames and out the window.  102 103 66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIXON lands on the sidewalk in a heap, his clothes all alight. He quickly pulls the case file out from under his shirt and tosses it as far away from the flames as he can It lands in a clean spot, no flames touching it, which ca be said for DIXON. He rolls around, trying to put himself out, but it’s just making it worse, he’s like a fireball. Across the street, MILDRED comes out of the WELBY buildin and sees him, horrified, just as JAMES turns a far corner sees DIXON on fire and MILDRED in the doorway. He sprints over and beats out the flames with his hands a clothes but DIXON’s head, hands and body are badly charre MILDRED turns away from him, horrified, and sees the case file lying there, and realises what DIXON has done, as th sirens and blue lights of the AMBULANCE and FIREMEN arriv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. Fire almost out, building ravaged. MILDRED sits exhausted on the sidewalk outside WELBY’s, JAMES beside h looking at her suspiciously. She looks away. ABERCROMBIE comes over.

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: (to MILDRED) So what did you see?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Well when we turned the corner from Spring, the fire was already raging, so, and then two seconds later the cop guy just jumps out the window...

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: Wait, the two of you turned the corner from Spring? Where were you before this?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Round at my place.

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: You two are boyfriend and girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Well, it’s early stages, y'know.

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: (to MILDRED) That right?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: We've had a couple dates.  104 67. ABERCROMBIE moves off, suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: So you wanna go out to dinner next week?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I/1l go out to dinner with ya. But T ain’t gonna fuck ya. She heads off.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Well, I ain’t gonna fuck you neither. (quietly) I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WELBY reading. A man, face and body bandaged (it’s DIXON, though WELBY can’t see this) is wheeled in by a NURSE.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (to WELBY) Burn victim. He’s pretty heavily sedated. NURSE leaves. WELBY hobbles over to take a look. Half DIX hair is gone and only his eyes are visible thru the banda

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Hey man? You doing okay? Jeez, you got burned up pretty bad. You'll be okay though, don’t worry. You want a glass of orange juice? I got a straw somewheres... The eyes behind the bandages start to cry. RED (CONT’D) Hey man, don’t cry. You'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Welby.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: (pause) You know me?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Sorry for what, man?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: For throwing you out the window.  106 68. WELBY realises finally, starts backing away.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Save it.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: I don’t care. And stop crying. The salt'll just fuck up your wounds.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I thought salt was supposed to be good for wounds.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Well what am I, a fucking doctor?! WELBY goes back to his bed. Sound of DIXON still crying. DIXON’S POV: Thru bandages, of the ceiling, him crying st Then the SOUND of liquid pouring. Then the SOUND of shuff steps. Then the POV catches WELBY, limping over. Carrying glass of orange juice. He places it beside DIXON’s bed an puts a straw in it. POV follows WELBY a little way back to his bed then drift the ceiling and remains there. As his crying continues. INT. MILDRED’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS 106 A knock on the front door. MILDRED looks out thru the spyhole, doesn’t recognise JEROME, who knocks again.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: JEROME, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Oh you don’t know me really.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Well what you want?

dialogues.speaker: JEROME, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: I come about the billboards.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: What about ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: JEROME, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They got burned up.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I know that.  69.

dialogues.speaker: JEROME, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m one of the guys who put the ‘em up in the first place. MILDRED opens door, safety latch on, vaguely recognises JEROME. JEROME (CONT’D) Jerome. They shake fingers thru the door.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: What can I do for ya, Jerome?

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: Well, y'know, when you're putting up a buncha posters like that, just in case any of ‘em gets screwed up or torn, they give ya a set of duplicates, y'know? JEROME shows her what he’s brought up. Thru the crack in door she sees two big card rolls full of posters.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (smiling) No, I didn’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that day. MILDRED and ROBBIE sloshing up the poster the ‘AND STILL NO ARRESTS’ billboard, as, distantly, JERO is finishing up with the first billboard. JAMES is holdin MILDRED's ladder steady, looking up at her.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Ladder’s pretty steady as it is, there, James.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t mind. I like holding ladders. It takes me out of myself. MILDRED sighs. A car pulls up. Out gets DENISE.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Need a hand? Squealing, MILDRED gets down, gives her a hug.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: When'd you get out?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Hour ago. Judge threw it out, said the arrest report weren’t filled out right. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Say, you didn’t burn down the police station, did ya?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: No. She was with me the whole night. DENISE looks at MILDRED.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (shakes head, mouthing) It’s a long story. JEROME comes up, having finished the first billboards. DE eyes him up, thinks he’s cute, it’s mutual, and they exch a ‘Hi’. JEROME holds up a part of the WILLOUGHBY poster.

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: You sure you still wanna put up the Willoughby one, him dead an’ all?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Why not? He paid for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some weeks later. A grey and windy evening. The posters a up beautifully, though the burned billboards look like th could crumble any second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIXON slouched low in a booth, morose, bandages gone, but burns still visible. In a distant corner, JEROME and DENI chat quietly. A truck pulls up outside. The CROP-HAIRED GUY and a male enter, order a couple of beers from TONY and sit in the b behind DIXON, not noticing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILDRED and JAMES at dinner at a nice restaurant, WAITER pouring wine. CHARLIE and PENELOPE enter and pass, CHARLI smiling at the sight of MILDRED with a dwarf. MILDRED has fleeting look of embarrassment, which JAMES registers.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Who's that?  71.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: My ex-husband. And his nineteen year old girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You wanna leave?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: No, no. A deal’s a deal. MILDRED smiles. JAMES only partly reciprocates. ull INT. BAR - NIGHT ull Murmured conversation behind DIXON as he peels the label his beer.

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It was fucking wild, man, I think I was certifiably fucking insane for a while back there.

dialogues.speaker: PAL, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: When was this?

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bout nine, ten months ago.

dialogues.speaker: PAL, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Were you on your own or what? DIXON is barely listening, as DENISE is staring hatefully him from across the bar. He ignores her, slugs some beer, the conversation behind him continues.

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, had a coupla buddies with me.

dialogues.speaker: PAL, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PAL, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: They fuck her too?

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I think they got their kicks just watching, you know.

dialogues.speaker: PAL, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Was she hot?

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: After the gasoline kicked in she was hot.  112 113 72. DIXON’s listening now. He gets up and ambles past their booth, to get an idea of who’s talking, but they clam up they notice him passing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIXON continues on out of the bar, lights a cigarette in trembling hands, takes out a pen, and makes a note of the TRUCK'S LICENSE PLATE. Finishes the cigarette, goes back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIXON ambles past their booth again, coming in on...

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: I ain't going down for that shit, last fucking day down there... GUY shuts up again as DIXON sits back in his booth. CROP-HAIRED GUY (CONT’D) (quietly) He been there the whole time?

dialogues.speaker: PAL
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: Burnt-face-Jake. Keeps fucking walking up and down.

dialogues.speaker: PAL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I don’t think so. GUY goes to the bar and turns to get a good look at DIXON who just stares at his beer. GUY gets two more beers and returns to his own booth, staring at him the whole way. D gets up, ambles to the bar, glancing at the GUY as he goe

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: Can I help you with something, man? You've been looking over here all fucking night, now, unless you got something to say to me, why don’t you take your burnt fucking face and get the fuck outta here, okay? Pause. DIXON goes over and sits in beside PAL, nudging hi over, facing the GUY. CROP-HAIRED GUY (CONT’D) What the fuck are you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait...  73. DIXON holds his hands up, back and front, so the GUY can there’s nothing in them, and that he means no harm.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just trust me, okay? DIXON reaches out with his empty right hand, slowly puts behind GUY’s right ear, GUY flinching slightly, exchangin glance with PAL. DIXON (CONT’D) Just trust me...

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: Just do the fucking trick. DIXON smiles, then quickly and deeply rakes his long fingernails down the GUY’s cheek, leaving a couple of dee bloody lines there. GUY and PAL spring at DIXON, pummelling him horrifically, reopening all his wounds. DIXON doesn’t fight back at all, in fact he just clutches fists to his chest to protect them. The two keep going an going, stamping on him sickeningly. JEROME stands up...

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: Hey! That’s enough now! GUY approaches, menacingly...

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: What's it to ya, fucker?

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: The guy’s a cop man! He’s a cop!

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? He ain’t wearing no badge.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: (thru blood) I lost my badge. I can't remember where I lost it.

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: You started this, man! I didn’t do shit to you.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I know I started it. I scratched you up like a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: CROP-HAIRED GUY
dialogues.text: That's exactly fucking right...  114 74. GUY kicks DIXON viciously in the head and exits with PAL, leaving DIXON lying there. Unmoving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILDRED and JAMES finishing their starters.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Gotta use the little boys’ room. JAMES goes off to the toilet. CHARLIE comes over, leaving PENELOPE hanging, sits in JAMES’ seat, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: You got something to say to me?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If I'd known, we coulda double-dated.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Doesn't shitgirl have a curfew weeknights?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, no, in fact I was actually gonna take her to the circus later, but there’s no need now. Does he juggle?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I’m having one dinner with the guy cos he did me a favor, okay?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to explain yourself to me cos you're having dinner with a midget, Mildred.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I’m not explaining myself to you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You kinda are. Across the room, PENELOPE makes a gesture about being lef alone, as JAMES comes back, sees CHARLIE in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen, I didn’t come over to break your balls, you can date as many midgets as you want. No, I came over to say I was sorry, actually.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Sorry for what? JAMES gets back onto his chair as CHARLIE gets out of it.  MILDRED just 75.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about what happened to your billboards an’ all.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Yeah well, that’s all water under the bridge now, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Good. I'm glad. I was pretty drunk, but it still don’t excuse it. stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All this anger, man, Penelope said to me the other day, it just begets greater anger, y'know? And it’s true.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Penelope said ‘Begets’?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, ‘It begets greater anger’. (to JAMES) Well, you take care of this little lady, okay sport? Big lady, compared to you, right? CHARLIE returns to his table. Silence between JAMES and MILDRED a while.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I think I'd like to go home now. JAMES just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aw don’t gimme any shit, James? We can do this another time, alright?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Why would I wanna do this another time? You've been embarrassed to be here ever since we arrived.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Oh for Christ’s sakes, James. I didn’t force you to come on this date, alright? You forced me.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Forced you? I asked you on a date. Wow! Well, y'know, I know I ain't much of a catch, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAMES climbs JAMES leaves 76.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know I'm a midget who sells used cars and has a drinking problem, I know that. But who the hell are you, man? You're that Billboard Lady who never ever smiles, who never has a good word to say about anybody, and who, in the eveningtimes, SETS FUCKING FIRE TO POLICE STATIONS! And I'M the one who's not a catch?! down off his chair...

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: James...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I didn’t have to come and hold your ladder! in tears, leaving MILDRED drained. She glances at CHARLIE. He’s smirking at the scene. MILDRED picks up her glass, picks up her half-empty bottle, and, holding it low at her side, slowly walks over to him. He loses his smile.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Now don’t make a scene. She looks the two of them over, bottle still in hand.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (to PENELOPE) Did you really tell him “Anger begets greater anger”?

dialogues.speaker: PENELOPE
dialogues.text: Oh! Yes! I did! I didn’t make it up myself though. I can’t claim that! No, I read it on a bookmark. (pause) Which was in a book I was reading. (pause) About polio. (pause) Polo. No, which is the one with the horses? Polio? Polo.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Polo.

dialogues.speaker: PENELOPE
dialogues.text: Polo! MILDRED looks at them a moment... then places the bottle the table for them to finish.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Be nice to her, Charlie. You got that?  118

dialogues.speaker: 118A
dialogues.text: 120 71. CHARLIE nods imperceptibly. MILDRED leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIXON staggers in, blood-soaked, past his horrified MOMMA

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA
dialogues.text: Jason!

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Just leave me, Momma, don’t look at me.

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA
dialogues.text: (crying) Jason! What have they done to you? INT. DIXON’S HOUSE, BATHROOM - CONTINUOUS 118A DIXON gets to the bathroom, slams door behind him, still clutching his right hand to his chest. He looks at himsel the cabinet mirror a second, repulsed by what he sees. He opens the cabinet mirror left-handed, rifles thru shel finds an unopened tweezer set, then finds a small clean g vial, a blank label on it. He sits on the bath and very slowly uses the tweezers to scrape out all the CROP-HAIRED GUY’S BLOOD AND SKIN trapp underneath the fingernails of his right hand, and careful places each amount inside the vial. Once all five fingernails are done he caps the vial and, in shaky hand, writes on its label ‘H5T371, IDAHO’. Finished, he clutches it to his chest and sinks to the fl shaking violently, MOMMA calling out, banging on the door

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jason?! Jason?!

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I’m gonna be alright, Momma. It’s all gonna be alright. INT. MILDRED’S HOUSE - DAY 120 MILDRED, glass of wine on couch, TV on but not really watching. Knock at the door. She goes to get it. Looks th the spyhole. SPYHOLE POV: Convex DIXON, new scars, bandages and a bean  78. 121 EXT. MILDRED’S GARDEN - DAY 121 MILDRED sitting on swing-set, DIXON with beanie in hand, repeat of Willoughby and his hat from long ago.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I don’t wanna get your hopes up, alright, but there’s a guy, and I think he might be the guy. I got his DNA. I got a lot of it, actually. They’re making the checks as we speak.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: He's in jail?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: No, but he ain’t gonna be hard to find.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Why do you think he’s the guy?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I heard him talking about something that he did to a girl in the middle of last year. I couldn’t hear all of it, but it sounded a lot like what happened to Angela. Then he beat the crap outta me. But cos of that I got a bunch of his DNA. So I wanted to let you know sooner rather than later. I didn’t want you to give up hope, y'know?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I’ve been trying not to.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Well, all you can do is try, as my Momma says. Not so much about hope as about... well, I didn’t used to be very good at English at school, so it was more “All you can do is try... to not be so crap at English.” Cos you need English, really, if you wanna be a cop. If you wanna be anything, really. (pause) unless you live in Mexico or something. But who wants that? He gets up to go.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Hey Dixon? (pause) Thanks. He smiles, and she watches him drive away, out past the billboards. She sits there a while, thinking.  79. 126 INT. POLICE STATION, WILLOUGHBY’S OFFICE - DAY 126 In the burnt-out office, DIXON is sitting down. ABERCROMB closes the office door and sits across from him.

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: You did good, Jason. You did real good. But he wasn’t the guy.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: (stunned) What?

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: There was no match to the DNA, no matches to any other crimes of this nature, to any crimes at all, in fact. And his record is clean. Maybe he was just bragging.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: He wasn’t just bragging.

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: Well, that’s as may be. But at the time of Angela’s death he wasn’t even in the country.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Where was he?

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: But I’ve seen his records of entry and exit to the States, and I’ve spoken to his Commanding Officer. He wasn’t in the country, Dixon. He ain’t our guy.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: He might not be our guy, but he still done something shitty.

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: Not in Missouri he didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Where was he?

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: That's classified information.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Come on, man.  127 129 80.

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: If the guy’s got a Commanding Officer, and if the guy got back to the country nine months ago, and if the country where he was is classified, which country do you think he was in? (pause) I’ll give you a clue. It was sandy.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: That doesn’t really narrow it down.

dialogues.speaker: ABERCROMBIE
dialogues.text: All you need to know is, he didn’t do nothing to Angela Hayes. So we’re gonna keep looking. Alright? Pause. DIXON takes out his badge, shows it to ABERCROMBIE

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I found my badge after all. DIXON looks at it a few seconds, then slides it across th table to ABERCROMBIE, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOMMA asleep, open-mouthed, on couch, TV on. DIXON watche her a while, then dials a number on the phone, which he t carries into his MOM’s bedroom, sitting on her bed. We no see that he has a shotgun in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILDRED trudging the dirt at the billboards, replacing th dead pot plants. At the third billboard, her cellphone ri

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's Dixon.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (pause) Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (pause) He wasn’t the guy. MILDRED crumples down beside the burnt patch of ground. S cries a quiet while, lets out a long, cold breath, then p the phone back up.  81.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I guess you're sure, right?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He, um, he wasn’t even in the country when it happened. So, whatever he did, he didn’t do it round here. (pause) I’m sorry I got your hopes up.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: It's alright. At least I had a day of hoping. Which is more than I’ve had for awhile. I'd better go. 129A INT. DIXON’S HOUSE, BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 129A DIXON idly taps the shotgun against his lips.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: um, there was one thing I was thinking.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Well,... I know he isn’t your rapist. He is a rapist, though. I’m sure of that.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I got his license plate. I know where he lives.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Where’s he live?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lives in Idaho.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: That's funny. I’m driving to Idaho in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Want some company?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (pause) sure.  130 131

dialogues.speaker: 131A
dialogues.text: 132 133 134 82. INT. DIXON’S HOUSE, BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 130 DIXON puts the phone back in its cradle. Looks at the gun his arms. Leaves it on his bed. He looks in on his sleepi MOMMA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The billboards as the sun begins to rise on the horizon. EXT. MILDRED’S HOUSE - DAWN 131A Sunrise behind the empty swing-set. INT. MILDRED’S HOUSE - DAWN 132 MILDRED looks in on ROBBIE, sleeping quietly, a drawing o Angela he’s done pinned on the wall above his pillow. EXT. MILDRED’S HOUSE - DAWN 133 MILDRED puts a thermos, sandwiches and Doritos in the car DIXON places a shotgun wrapped in a blanket inside too. MILDRED looks at it lying there. They exchange a look, ge the car and drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The burned backs of the billboards framed along the roads as the car heads away towards the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the car rolls along the road, they’re both quiet, nerv They drive in silence a while.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Hey Dixon?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: I need to tell you something. (pause) It was me who burned down the police station.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Well, who the Hell else would it have been?  83. She smiles. They drive on in silence.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: Dixon?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Yep?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: You sure about this?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: About killing this guy? (pause) Not really. You?

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: (pause) Not really. They continue on.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I guess we can decide along the way. DIXON nods. She smiles. They drive on.
